title: Are You Guilty of #039;Phubbing#039;?
text:
Get Business & Technology Alerts 
3 Oct 2015 04:56 AM EST 
In theory, when you’re in a relationship, the temptation to seek emotional relief from isolation through your phone should be reduced. But according to a survey of more than 400 individuals by Baylor University, 46.3% of respondents said their partners snubbed them by taking to their phones. Ignoring someone by interacting with one's phone is called “phubbing." Co-authors James E. Roberts and M.E. David write, "it appears that life has become a major distraction from our cell phones. It is ironic that cell phones, originally designed as a communication tool, may actually hinder rather than foster satisfying relationships among romantic partners."
